posts.name:
Yurii Veremchuk
Yurii Veremchuk
posts.content:
Don't send a LinkedIn DM that starts with: "Hope this message finds you well‚Äù

Why so serious?... Try doing this instead:

1 Relevant + Good Timing + Personalised
‚Ä¢ 2-3 sentences max. Make it look like a text, not an email.
‚Ä¢ Let your ‚Äúwhy‚Äù stand out in the 1st line of a DM.

2. Value + Social Proof
‚Ä¢ Show that the Status QUO is not desirable by focusing on Cost of Inaction
‚Ä¢ Infuse social proof = build trust faster

3. End strongly
‚Ä¢ End with ONE clear call-to-action.
‚Ä¢ Be super specific about what you‚Äôre asking for

Use this formula if you want

Name - <observation>, <value>. <social proof> + <risk reversal>. <CTA>.

 Personalized + relevant + direct-to-the-point DMs are evergreen.

What would you add?

comments.commentText: In 99 % their message does not find me well.
Daria P. Haha same here
Daria P. That sucks. I'm well at the very least 50% of the time. If you're genuinely not well 99% of the time I think your problems are bigger than LinkedIn.
I love your humor. do you have a good example to share?
Berna Geylani good example of a joke? :) or a DM?

posts.name:
Dan Goodman
Dan Goodman
posts.content:
Write the check. 

Writing a $100k commission check to a top rep should be a dream come true for any organization.

If you built a comp plan and you‚Äôre paying a rep a $100k commission against your plan, you should be celebrating. Literally. You both won massively.

Pay the $100k and send the rep and their spouse on a trip. Encourage them to post about it and shout it from the rooftops.

Don‚Äôt fire them and steal from them. How it ever became an option never mind a consideration is beyond me.

Take the opportunity to throw a company-wide celebration. Get a blown-up check (2‚Äô x 4‚Äô) and present it to the rep in front of the entire company. Nothing will be more motivating for everyone.

Talk about building corporate culture, trust, and camaraderie. This is how you attract and retain top talent. Pay them for what they are, rock stars that drive your revenue.

That $100k check is attached to a $1m deal. Which could add $10m in enterprise value to an early stage company. Think about it.

Don't let your ego get in the way of running and growing your company. It is OK to pay a top rep more than the c-suite earns. They have the equity. They have the big, fat year-end bonuses earned off the backs of their reps.

Let's all win together. Do the right thing. It will cost you a lot more in the long run than any savings today.

Long-term view > short-term view every day.

Write the check, you owe it to your rep and your company.

comments.commentText:
Dan Goodman are you saying don‚Äôt celebrate a salesperson taking the company to a revenue milestone never seen before in all hands and then let them go an hour later offering peanuts severance? 

Yes would agree
I love it when you bring the east coast sarcasm my friend. Yes, that is exactly what I mean. Darin Alpert

I had a situation like this with a previous employer. Hard fought renewal that initially looked like there would be significant revenue churn. The chief commerical officer wanted to accept it vs losing the client. I persisted and we were successful in renewing the client with a 5% increase in fees. A deal worth over $1,400,000.

We hadn‚Äôt received comp plans for the year but under the previous plan it would have been a five figure commission. After the deal was closed the new plans rolled out and the commission was reduced to $4,500. Then we were laid off anyway and told we wouldn‚Äôt be paid anything.
David Kaduk sadly it sounds like you dodged a bullet there. I hope they learned their lesson, although I imagine they may not have. This kind of behavior is totally unacceptable.

posts.name:
Neha K Puri
Neha K Puri
posts.content:
Why wait until employees leave to understand what matters to them? Instead of conducting exit interviews to understand why people LEFT, let's start doing "stay interviews" to understand why they STAY.

Companies like,, and(yes, this platform!) have already embraced this proactive approach.

The results? Higher retention rates and more engaged teams.

What makes stay interviews different?

‚Ä¢ They focus on what's working, not what failed

‚Ä¢ They give you time to act on feedback

‚Ä¢ They make employees feel valued NOW

Key questions smart leaders are asking:

1. "What growth opportunities are you seeking?"

2. "How can we better support your career goals?"

3. "What's one thing we could change to make your experience better?"

Studies show that by the time an employee gives notice, they've been mentally checked out for an average of 6-8 months. Why wait that long?

I recently spoke with a tech lead who said, "Exit interviews are like asking for relationship advice after the divorce." Ouch, but true!

Don't wait until it's too late. The best time to understand what keeps your top talent engaged is while they're still passionate about their work.

Has your company tried conducting stay interviews?

comments.commentText: Every organization should have anonymous quarterly ‚ÄòEmployee Satisfaction‚Äô surveys to gauge employees job satisfaction. Anonymous because in my experience when people give feedback on the workplace negatives and area for improvement, it‚Äôs often taken in the wrong way. Some might argue, ‚Äòideally a workplace environment should be open enough to allow and value team input‚Äô, however if the culture is already toxic or there are toxic managers, people won‚Äôt share their feedback.

posts.name:
üèÑ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Scott Leese
üèÑ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Scott Leese
posts.content:
Rough start to the year? What is delayed is not denied.

________________________________


‚ÄúFrom time to time in the years to come, I hope you will be treated unfairly, so that you will come to know the value of justice.

I hope that you will suffer betrayal because that will teach you the importance of loyalty.

Sorry to say, but I hope you will be lonely from time to time so that you don‚Äôt take friends for granted.

I wish you bad luck, again, from time to time so that you will be conscious of the role of chance in life and understand that your success is not completely deserved and that the failure of others is not completely deserved either.

And when you lose, as you will from time to time, I hope every now and then, your opponent will gloat over your failure. It is a way for you to understand the importance of sportsmanship.

I hope you‚Äôll be ignored so you know the importance of listening to others, and I hope you will have just enough pain to learn compassion.

Whether I wish these things or not, they‚Äôre going to happen.

And whether you benefit from them or not will depend upon your ability to see the message in your misfortunes.‚Äù

_______________________________

In my experience, everybody's lives are some form of a "mess", and it's simply the ones who translate the messages into energy and fuel and wisdom who succeed.

Tell yourself a story - reframe suffering into a superpower.

comments.commentText: 100% struggles and setbacks are inevitable but they hold valuable lessons that shape growth and resilience

posts.name:
Ashley Couto
Ashley Couto
posts.content:
10 ways to stay sane during your job search 

(And not let it take over your whole life)

The job search can feel like a full-time job.
Except... there's no paycheck or clear feedback.
And somehow... there's even more meetings.

To quote Maddy Perez:
First of all... ew.
Second of all... ew.

In all seriousness... job searches are the worst.
They're basically guaranteed to stress you out.
Even if you do it while you have a job.

If you're feeling stressed in your search, I get it.
I help people with their job search every single day.
But I recently went through a job search myself...

And I still did the post-interview email hyper refresh.

Here's how I (mostly) kept my cool & you can, too:

1/ Create a structured "job search schedule"
‚Ü≥ Treat it like a project, not your whole life.

2/ Set weekly action-based goals
‚Ü≥ Use SMART goals to help you.

3/ Track your progress visually
‚Ü≥ See your momentum, not just outcomes.

4/ Prep for your interviews
‚Ü≥ They're the final exams of adulthood.

5/ Lean into your skill development
‚Ü≥ Use the opportunity to grow.

6/ Limit negative self-talk
‚Ü≥ Give yourself grace in the process.

7/ Develop a post-rejection ritual
‚Ü≥ Process, learn, then release.

8/ Journal & practice gratitude
‚Ü≥ Ground yourself before you open the laptop.

9/ Rely on your support system
‚Ü≥ But don't listen to every bit of their advice.

10/ Touch grass (literally)
‚Ü≥ Get some fresh air & connect to nature.

Keep your head up. You've got this.

Q: How did you celebrate your last job offer?

Ô∏è Repost to help a job seeker
 Followfor daily career insights

comments.commentText:
I have somebody I‚Äôm sending this too immediately. 

I remember an early job search where I was applying for jobs I didn‚Äôt even want, then they‚Äôd say I was overqualified and reject me and then I‚Äôd be even more sad/angry/overwhelmed and worked myself into a little spiral. I needed to read this at the time.
Glad you had someone in mind for this, Leslie. I have made the same mistake and paid the emotional toll for it earlier.

posts.name:
Matthew Buchalski
Matthew Buchalski
posts.content:
The best people I‚Äôve ever hired all have one thing in common: they show up prepared and take the process seriously.

They treat the interview like the single most important sale they‚Äôll make‚Äîbecause it is.

Think about it: you‚Äôre selling yourself.

The best candidates:
‚óè Demonstrate knowledge of the company, the opportunity, and the market.
‚óè Research the hiring manager and the team they‚Äôll be joining.
‚óè Backchannel information where they can, digging deeper to understand the culture and how they‚Äôll fit.
‚óè Show up ready to speak the language of the role they‚Äôre pursuing.

Too many people take interviewing too lightly.

They don‚Äôt prepare or give it a second thought once the Zoom invite is sent.

But a great candidate knows this is their chance to close the deal on their future.

A perfect example?

When I hired Matt, at RealPage, he came to the interview with all the details dialed in.

He knew about me, my background, my social media presence, and even that I had a family.

He did his homework.

He knew his stuff. He wasn‚Äôt just selling himself‚Äîhe was proving that he‚Äôd done the work to win the opportunity. Most importantly, he showed me that he not only knew the right steps but that he could teach them to others.

Most candidates skip this step.

They come in blind and hope for the best.

They wing it.

But the best hires? They leave nothing to chance.

If you‚Äôre looking for your next role, treat the interview process like a sales cycle.

Research, prepare, and close.

Because in a competitive market, being prepared isn‚Äôt optional‚Äîit‚Äôs how you win.

comments.commentText: The hard part was figuring out how to slip "Booch Nasty" into my interview answers

posts.name:
Jake Dunlap
Jake Dunlap
posts.content:
The days of sticking to outdated buyer models where we expect buyers to just adapt to our process are long behind us

Our new reality is buyers who want us to show up already understanding their challenges and goals. They‚Äôre not here to explain their ‚Äúneed‚Äù or jump through a bunch of qualification hoops

It‚Äôs on us to do the work upfront

Our ability to connect as humans not just sellers has never been more critical than it is right now

And here‚Äôs the kicker: AI isn‚Äôt replacing that connection. It‚Äôs actually a tool we can use to enhance it. So when you‚Äôre faced with the question ‚ÄúDoes AI know your buyer better than you?‚Äù you won‚Äôt be afraid of the answer

This isn‚Äôt about competing with AI. It‚Äôs about learning from it and using it to be better. Better personas. Better outreach. Stronger connections

In today‚Äôs episode of Innovative Seller, we‚Äôre breaking it all down: the death of generic outreach, the rise of AI, and how to create buyer models that actually work in 2025

Today's episode is live now over on YouTube. Give it a watch and let me know your thoughts in the comments

comments.commentText: Truly loving your content.....by the way, love your communication cadence, tempo etc. I recognize the intentional hard work there, it's not easy Jake Dunlap

posts.name:
The Social Media Marketing Group
The Social Media Marketing Group
posts.content:
Today, I read a WSJ story about someone who applied to over 260 jobs. After facing rejection after rejection, her big break came when someone she knew stepped up and vouched for her.

This story hits home for anyone who‚Äôs been ignored by clients, companies, or people they‚Äôre trying to impress. The truth is that success often comes from building real connections. Networking isn‚Äôt about quick wins‚Äîit‚Äôs about trust and relationships.

Your network can open doors, but it takes effort to grow it. Did you know 81% of people say trust is the main reason they choose to work with someone? That‚Äôs why building a personal brand is so important. It‚Äôs not just about being seen‚Äîit‚Äôs about being trusted. When you‚Äôre intentional about your personal brand, you can show off your strengths and connect with people in a real way.

Don‚Äôt let your reputation just ‚Äúhappen.‚Äù Start working on your personal brand now‚Äîit‚Äôs one of your greatest strengths in a competitive world.

This Personal Branding Balanced Scorecard is here to help you get started in 2025. Let me know what you think!
